017package org.parboiled;
018
019import org.parboiled.annotations.*;
020import org.parboiled.common.Utils;
021import org.parboiled.errors.GrammarException;
022import org.parboiled.matchers.*;
023import org.parboiled.parse.Action;
024import org.parboiled.parse.Rule;
025import org.parboiled.support.Characters;
026import org.parboiled.support.Chars;
027import org.parboiled.support.Checks;
028
029import java.util.Arrays;
030
031import static org.parboiled.common.Preconditions.*;
032
033/**
034 * Base class of all parboiled parsers. Defines the basic rule creation methods.
035 *
036 * @param <V> the type of the parser values
037 */
038@SuppressWarnings( {"UnusedDeclaration"})
039public abstract class BaseParser<V> extends BaseActions<V> {
040
041    /**
042     * Matches the {@link Chars#EOI} (end of input) character.
043     */
044    public static final Rule EOI = new CharMatcher(Chars.EOI);
045
046    /**
047     * Matches the special {@link Chars#INDENT} character produces by the org.parboiled.buffers.IndentDedentInputBuffer
048     */
049    public static final Rule INDENT = new CharMatcher(Chars.INDENT);
050
051    /**
052     * Matches the special {@link Chars#DEDENT} character produces by the org.parboiled.buffers.IndentDedentInputBuffer
053     */
054    public static final Rule DEDENT = new CharMatcher(Chars.DEDENT);
055
056    /**
057     * Matches any character except {@link Chars#EOI}.
058     */
059    public static final Rule ANY = new AnyMatcher();
060
061    /**
062     * Matches nothing and always succeeds.
063     */
064    public static final Rule EMPTY = new EmptyMatcher();
065
066    /**
067     * Matches nothing and always fails.
068     */
069    public static final Rule NOTHING = new NothingMatcher();
070
071    /**
072     * Creates a new instance of this parsers class using the no-arg constructor. If no no-arg constructor
073     * exists this method will fail with a java.lang.NoSuchMethodError.
074     * Using this method is faster than using {@link Parboiled#createParser(Class, Object...)} for creating
075     * new parser instances since this method does not use reflection.
076     *
077     * @param <P> the parser class
078     * @return a new parser instance
079     */
080    public <P extends BaseParser<V>> P newInstance() {
081        throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
082                "Illegal parser instance, you have to use Parboiled.createParser(...) to create your parser instance!");
083    }
084
085    /**
086     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given character. Normally you can just specify the character literal
087     * directly in you rule description. However, if you don't want to go through {@link #fromCharLiteral(char)},
088     * e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.
089     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
090     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
091     *
092     * @param c the char to match
093     * @return a new rule
094     */
095    @Cached
096    @DontLabel
097    public Rule Ch(char c) {
098        return new CharMatcher(c);
099    }
100
101    /**
102     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given character case-independently.
103     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
104     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
105     *
106     * @param c the char to match independently of its case
107     * @return a new rule
108     */
109    @Cached
110    @DontLabel
111    public Rule IgnoreCase(char c) {
112        if (Character.isLowerCase(c) == Character.isUpperCase(c)) {
113            return Ch(c);
114        }
115        return new CharIgnoreCaseMatcher(c);
116    }
117
118    /**
119     * Creates a rule matching a range of characters from cLow to cHigh (both inclusively).
120     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
121     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
122     *
123     * @param cLow  the start char of the range (inclusively)
124     * @param cHigh the end char of the range (inclusively)
125     * @return a new rule
126     */
127    @Cached
128    @DontLabel
129    public Rule CharRange(char cLow, char cHigh) {
130        return cLow == cHigh ? Ch(cLow) : new CharRangeMatcher(cLow, cHigh);
131    }
132
133    /**
134     * Creates a new rule that matches any of the characters in the given string.
135     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
136     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
137     *
138     * @param characters the characters
139     * @return a new rule
140     */
141    @DontLabel
142    public Rule AnyOf(String characters) {
143        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
144        return AnyOf(characters.toCharArray());
145    }
146
147    /**
148     * Creates a new rule that matches any of the characters in the given char array.
149     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
150     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
151     *
152     * @param characters the characters
153     * @return a new rule
154     */
155    @DontLabel
156    public Rule AnyOf(char[] characters) {
157        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
158        checkArgument(characters.length > 0);
159        return characters.length == 1 ? Ch(characters[0]) : AnyOf(Characters.of(characters));
160    }
161
162    /**
163     * Creates a new rule that matches any of the given characters.
164     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
165     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
166     *
167     * @param characters the characters
168     * @return a new rule
169     */
170    @Cached
171    @DontLabel
172    public Rule AnyOf(Characters characters) {
173        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
174        if (!characters.isSubtractive() && characters.getChars().length == 1) {
175            return Ch(characters.getChars()[0]);
176        }
177        if (characters.equals(Characters.NONE)) return NOTHING;
178        return new AnyOfMatcher(characters);
179    }
180
181    /**
182     * Creates a new rule that matches all characters except the ones in the given string and EOI.
183     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
184     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
185     *
186     * @param characters the characters
187     * @return a new rule
188     */
189    @DontLabel
190    public Rule NoneOf(String characters) {
191        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
192        return NoneOf(characters.toCharArray());
193    }
194
195    /**
196     * Creates a new rule that matches all characters except the ones in the given char array and EOI.
197     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
198     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
199     *
200     * @param characters the characters
201     * @return a new rule
202     */
203    @DontLabel
204    public Rule NoneOf(char[] characters) {
205        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
206        checkArgument(characters.length > 0);
207
208        // make sure to always exclude EOI as well
209        boolean containsEOI = false;
210        for (char c : characters) if (c == Chars.EOI) { containsEOI = true; break; }
211        if (!containsEOI) {
212            char[] withEOI = new char[characters.length + 1];
213            System.arraycopy(characters, 0, withEOI, 0, characters.length);
214            withEOI[characters.length] = Chars.EOI;
215            characters = withEOI;
216        }
217
218        return AnyOf(Characters.allBut(characters));
219    }
220
221    /**
222     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string. Normally you can just specify the string literal
223     * directly in you rule description. However, if you want to not go through {@link #fromStringLiteral(String)},
224     * e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.
225     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
226     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
227     *
228     * @param string the String to match
229     * @return a new rule
230     */
231    @DontLabel
232    public Rule String(String string) {
233        checkArgNotNull(string, "string");
234        return String(string.toCharArray());
235    }
236
237    /**
238     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string. Normally you can just specify the string literal
239     * directly in you rule description. However, if you want to not go through {@link #fromStringLiteral(String)},
240     * e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.
241     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
242     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
243     *
244     * @param characters the characters of the string to match
245     * @return a new rule
246     */
247    @Cached
248    @SuppressSubnodes
249    @DontLabel
250    public Rule String(char... characters) {
251        if (characters.length == 1) return Ch(characters[0]); // optimize one-char strings
252        Rule[] matchers = new Rule[characters.length];
253        for (int i = 0; i < characters.length; i++) {
254            matchers[i] = Ch(characters[i]);
255        }
256        return new StringMatcher(matchers, characters);
257    }
258
259    /**
260     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string in a case-independent fashion.
261     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
262     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
263     *
264     * @param string the string to match
265     * @return a new rule
266     */
267    @DontLabel
268    public Rule IgnoreCase(String string) {
269        checkArgNotNull(string, "string");
270        return IgnoreCase(string.toCharArray());
271    }
272
273    /**
274     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string in a case-independent fashion.
275     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
276     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
277     *
278     * @param characters the characters of the string to match
279     * @return a new rule
280     */
281    @Cached
282    @SuppressSubnodes
283    @DontLabel
284    public Rule IgnoreCase(char... characters) {
285        if (characters.length == 1) return IgnoreCase(characters[0]); // optimize one-char strings
286        Rule[] matchers = new Rule[characters.length];
287        for (int i = 0; i < characters.length; i++) {
288            matchers[i] = IgnoreCase(characters[i]);
289        }
290        return ((SequenceMatcher) Sequence(matchers)).label('"' + String.valueOf(characters) + '"');
291    }
292
293    /**
294     * Creates a new rule that successively tries all of the given subrules and succeeds when the first one of
295     * its subrules matches. If all subrules fail this rule fails as well.
296     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
297     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
298     *
299     * @param rule      the first subrule
300     * @param rule2     the second subrule
301     * @param moreRules the other subrules
302     * @return a new rule
303     */
304    @DontLabel
305    public Rule FirstOf(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
306        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
307        return FirstOf(Utils.arrayOf(rule, rule2, moreRules));
308    }
309
310    /**
311     * Creates a new rule that successively tries all of the given subrules and succeeds when the first one of
312     * its subrules matches. If all subrules fail this rule fails as well.
313     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
314     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
315     *
316     * @param rules the subrules
317     * @return a new rule
318     */
319    @Cached
320    @DontLabel
321    public Rule FirstOf(Object[] rules) {
322        checkArgNotNull(rules, "rules");
323        if (rules.length == 1) {
324            return toRule(rules[0]);
325        }
326        Rule[] convertedRules = toRules(rules);
327        char[][] chars = new char[rules.length][];
328        for (int i = 0, convertedRulesLength = convertedRules.length; i < convertedRulesLength; i++) {
329            Object rule = convertedRules[i];
330            if (rule instanceof StringMatcher) {
331                chars[i] = ((StringMatcher) rule).characters;
332            } else {
333                return new FirstOfMatcher(convertedRules);
334            }
335        }
336        return new FirstOfStringsMatcher(convertedRules, chars);
337    }
338
339    /**
340     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of its subrule and succeeds if the subrule matches at least once.
341     * If the subrule does not match at least once this rule fails.
342     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
343     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
344     *
345     * @param rule the subrule
346     * @return a new rule
347     */
348    @Cached
349    @DontLabel
350    public Rule OneOrMore(Object rule) {
351        return new OneOrMoreMatcher(toRule(rule));
352    }
353
354    /**
355     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of a sequence of the given subrules and succeeds if the sequence
356     * matches at least once. If the sequence does not match at least once this rule fails.
357     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
358     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
359     *
360     * @param rule      the first subrule
361     * @param rule2     the second subrule
362     * @param moreRules the other subrules
363     * @return a new rule
364     */
365    @DontLabel
366    public Rule OneOrMore(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
367        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
368        return OneOrMore(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
369    }
370
371    /**
372     * Creates a new rule that tries a match on its subrule and always succeeds, independently of the matching
373     * success of its sub rule.
374     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
375     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
376     *
377     * @param rule the subrule
378     * @return a new rule
379     */
380    @Cached
381    @DontLabel
382    public Rule Optional(Object rule) {
383        return new OptionalMatcher(toRule(rule));
384    }
385
386    /**
387     * Creates a new rule that tries a match on the sequence of the given subrules and always succeeds, independently
388     * of the matching success of its sub sequence.
389     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
390     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
391     *
392     * @param rule      the first subrule
393     * @param rule2     the second subrule
394     * @param moreRules the other subrules
395     * @return a new rule
396     */
397    @DontLabel
398    public Rule Optional(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
399        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
400        return Optional(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
401    }
402
403    /**
404     * Creates a new rule that only succeeds if all of its subrule succeed, one after the other.
405     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
406     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
407     *
408     * @param rule      the first subrule
409     * @param rule2     the second subrule
410     * @param moreRules the other subrules
411     * @return a new rule
412     */
413    @DontLabel
414    public Rule Sequence(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
415        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
416        return Sequence(Utils.arrayOf(rule, rule2, moreRules));
417    }
418
419    /**
420     * Creates a new rule that only succeeds if all of its subrule succeed, one after the other.
421     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
422     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
423     *
424     * @param rules the sub rules
425     * @return a new rule
426     */
427    @Cached
428    @DontLabel
429    public Rule Sequence(Object[] rules) {
430        checkArgNotNull(rules, "rules");
431        return rules.length == 1 ? toRule(rules[0]) : new SequenceMatcher(toRules(rules));
432    }
433
434    /**
435     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as a syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the given sub rule against the current
436     * input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub rule succeeds and fails if the
437     * sub rule rails. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a parse tree node.</p>
438     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
439     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
440     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
441     * Also see {@link org.parboiled.annotations.SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
442     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
443     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
444     *
445     * @param rule the subrule
446     * @return a new rule
447     */
448    @Cached
449    @SuppressNode
450    @DontLabel
451    public Rule Test(Object rule) {
452        Rule subMatcher = toRule(rule);
453        return new TestMatcher(subMatcher);
454    }
455
456    /**
457     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as a syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the sequence of the given sub rule against
458     * the current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub sequence succeeds and
459     * fails if the sub sequence rails. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a
460     * parse tree node.</p>
461     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
462     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
463     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
464     * Also see {@link org.parboiled.annotations.SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
465     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
466     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
467     *
468     * @param rule      the first subrule
469     * @param rule2     the second subrule
470     * @param moreRules the other subrules
471     * @return a new rule
472     */
473    @DontLabel
474    public Rule Test(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
475        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
476        return Test(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
477    }
478
479    /**
480     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as an inverse syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the given sub rule against the
481     * current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub rule fails and fails if the
482     * sub rule succeeds. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a parse tree node.</p>
483     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
484     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
485     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
486     * Also see {@link org.parboiled.annotations.SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
487     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
488     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
489     *
490     * @param rule the subrule
491     * @return a new rule
492     */
493    @Cached
494    @SuppressNode
495    @DontLabel
496    public Rule TestNot(Object rule) {
497        Rule subMatcher = toRule(rule);
498        return new TestNotMatcher(subMatcher);
499    }
500
501    /**
502     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as an inverse syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the sequence of the given sub rules
503     * against the current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub sequence fails
504     * and fails if the sub sequence succeeds. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create
505     * a parse tree node.</p>
506     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
507     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
508     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
509     * Also see {@link org.parboiled.annotations.SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
510     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
511     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
512     *
513     * @param rule      the first subrule
514     * @param rule2     the second subrule
515     * @param moreRules the other subrules
516     * @return a new rule
517     */
518    @DontLabel
519    public Rule TestNot(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
520        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
521        return TestNot(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
522    }
523
524    /**
525     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of its subrule.
526     * Succeeds always, even if the subrule doesn't match even once.
527     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
528     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
529     *
530     * @param rule the subrule
531     * @return a new rule
532     */
533    @Cached
534    @DontLabel
535    public Rule ZeroOrMore(Object rule) {
536        return new ZeroOrMoreMatcher(toRule(rule));
537    }
538
539    /**
540     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of the sequence of the given sub rules.
541     * Succeeds always, even if the sub sequence doesn't match even once.
542     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
543     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
544     *
545     * @param rule      the first subrule
546     * @param rule2     the second subrule
547     * @param moreRules the other subrules
548     * @return a new rule
549     */
550    @DontLabel
551    public Rule ZeroOrMore(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
552        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
553        return ZeroOrMore(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
554    }
555
556    /**
557     * Creates a new rule that repeatedly matches a given sub rule a certain fixed number of times.
558     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
559     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
560     *
561     * @param repetitions The number of repetitions to match. Must be >= 0.
562     * @param rule      the sub rule to match repeatedly.
563     * @return a new rule
564     */
565    @Cached
566    @DontLabel
567    public Rule NTimes(int repetitions, Object rule) {
568        return NTimes(repetitions, rule, null);
569    }
570
571    /**
572     * Creates a new rule that repeatedly matches a given sub rule a certain fixed number of times, optionally
573     * separated by a given separator rule.
574     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
575     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
576     *
577     * @param repetitions The number of repetitions to match. Must be >= 0.
578     * @param rule      the sub rule to match repeatedly.
579     * @param separator the separator to match, if null the individual sub rules will be matched without separator.
580     * @return a new rule
581     */
582    @Cached
583    @DontLabel
584    public Rule NTimes(int repetitions, Object rule, Object separator) {
585        checkArgNotNull(rule, "rule");
586        checkArgument(repetitions >= 0, "repetitions must be non-negative");
587        switch (repetitions) {
588            case 0: return EMPTY;
589            case 1: return toRule(rule);
590            default:
591                Object[] rules = new Object[separator == null ? repetitions : repetitions * 2 - 1];
592                if (separator != null) {
593                    for (int i = 0; i < rules.length; i++)
594                        rules[i] = i % 2 == 0 ? rule : separator;
595                } else Arrays.fill(rules, rule);
596                return Sequence(rules);
597        }
598    }
599
600    ///************************* "MAGIC" METHODS ***************************///
601
602    /**
603     * Explicitly marks the wrapped expression as an action expression.
604     * parboiled transforms the wrapped expression into an {@link Action} instance during parser construction.
605     *
606     * @param expression the expression to turn into an Action
607     * @return the Action wrapping the given expression
608     */
609    public static Action ACTION(boolean expression) {
610        throw new UnsupportedOperationException("ACTION(...) calls can only be used in Rule creating parser methods");
611    }
612
613    ///************************* HELPER METHODS ***************************///
614
615    /**
616     * Used internally to convert the given character literal to a parser rule.
617     * You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a Sequence that automatically matches all trailing
618     * whitespace after the character.
619     *
620     * @param c the character
621     * @return the rule
622     */
623    @DontExtend
624    protected Rule fromCharLiteral(char c) {
625        return Ch(c);
626    }
627
628    /**
629     * Used internally to convert the given string literal to a parser rule.
630     * You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a Sequence that automatically matches all trailing
631     * whitespace after the string.
632     *
633     * @param string the string
634     * @return the rule
635     */
636    @DontExtend
637    protected Rule fromStringLiteral(String string) {
638        checkArgNotNull(string, "string");
639        return fromCharArray(string.toCharArray());
640    }
641
642    /**
643     * Used internally to convert the given char array to a parser rule.
644     * You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a Sequence that automatically matches all trailing
645     * whitespace after the characters.
646     *
647     * @param array the char array
648     * @return the rule
649     */
650    @DontExtend
651    protected Rule fromCharArray(char[] array) {
652        checkArgNotNull(array, "array");
653        return String(array);
654    }
655
656    /**
657     * Converts the given object array to an array of rules.
658     *
659     * @param objects the objects to convert
660     * @return the rules corresponding to the given objects
661     */
662    @DontExtend
663    public Rule[] toRules(Object... objects) {
664        checkArgNotNull(objects, "objects");
665        Rule[] rules = new Rule[objects.length];
666        for (int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++) {
667            rules[i] = toRule(objects[i]);
668        }
669        return rules;
670    }
671
672    /**
673     * Converts the given object to a rule.
674     * This method can be overriden to enable the use of custom objects directly in rule specifications.
675     *
676     * @param obj the object to convert
677     * @return the rule corresponding to the given object
678     */
679    @DontExtend
680    public Rule toRule(Object obj) {
681        if (obj instanceof Rule) return (Rule) obj;
682        if (obj instanceof Character) return fromCharLiteral((Character) obj);
683        if (obj instanceof String) return fromStringLiteral((String) obj);
684        if (obj instanceof char[]) return fromCharArray((char[]) obj);
685        if (obj instanceof Action) {
686            Action action = (Action) obj;
687            return new ActionMatcher(action);
688        }
689        Checks.ensure(!(obj instanceof Boolean), "Rule specification contains an unwrapped Boolean value, " +
690                "if you were trying to specify a parser action wrap the expression with ACTION(...)");
691
692        throw new GrammarException("'" + obj + "' cannot be automatically converted to a parser Rule");
693    }
694
695}
